SEARCH
Package io.github.kusoroadeolu.ferrous.result

Interface Result<T,E>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the success value
E - the type of the error value
All Known Implementing Classes:
Err, Ok
public sealed interface Result<T,E> permits Ok<T,E>, Err<T,E>
A type representing either success (Ok) or failure (Err).

Result is used for operations that can fail in a predictable way, providing type-safe error handling without exceptions. It forces explicit handling of both success and error cases, making error paths visible in the type system.

A Result can be queried with isOk() and isErr(), and values can be extracted with unwrap(), unwrapOr(Object), or pattern matching. Operations can be chained using map(Function), flatMap(Function), and other combinators.

Example: 


 Result<User, DatabaseError> findUser(String id) {
     return validateUserId(id)
         .flatMap(validId -> queryDatabase(validId))
         .flatMap(row -> parseUser(row));
 }

 // Handle the result
 String username = findUser("123")
     .map(User::getName)
     .unwrapOr("Unknown");
See Also:
  • Ok
  • Err
  • Option

  • Method Details

    • ok

      static <T, E> Result<T,E> ok(@NonNull T value)
      Creates a Result representing a successful operation.

      Example: 

      
 Result<String, Error> success = Result.ok("hello");
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the success value
      E - the type of the error value
      Parameters:
      value - the success value
      Returns:
      an Ok containing the value
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if value is null

    • err

      static <T, E> Result<T,E> err(@NonNull E error)
      Creates a Result representing a failed operation.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the success value
      E - the type of the error value
      Parameters:
      error - the error value
      Returns:
      an Err containing the error
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if error is null

    • catching

      static <T> @NonNull Result<T,Exception> catching(@NonNull ThrowingSupplier<T> supplier)
      Wraps a throwing supplier in a Result, catching any exceptions. If supplier succeeds: returns Ok(value) If supplier throws: returns Err(exception)
      Type Parameters:
      T - the success type
      Parameters:
      supplier - the throwing supplier to execute
      Returns:
      Ok if successful, Err containing the exception if it throws

    • catching

      static <T, E> @NonNull Result<T,E> catching(@NonNull ThrowingSupplier<T> supplier, @NonNull Function<Exception,E> errorMapper)
      Wraps a throwing supplier in a Result, mapping exceptions with the provided function. If supplier succeeds: returns Ok(value) If supplier throws: returns Err(errorMapper(exception))
      Type Parameters:
      T - the success type
      E - the error type
      Parameters:
      supplier - the throwing supplier to execute
      errorMapper - function to map exceptions to error type
      Returns:
      Ok if successful, Err with mapped exception if it throws

    • catching

      static <T, R> @NonNull Result<R,Exception> catching(@NonNull ThrowingFunction<T,R> fn, @NonNull T input)
      Wraps a throwing function in a Result, catching any exceptions. If function succeeds: returns Ok(value) If function throws: returns Err(exception)
      Type Parameters:
      T - the input type
      R - the success type
      Parameters:
      fn - the throwing function to execute
      input - the input value
      Returns:
      Ok if successful, Err containing the exception if it throws

    • catching

      static <T, R, E> @NonNull Result<R,E> catching(@NonNull ThrowingFunction<T,@NonNull R> fn, @NonNull T input, @NonNull Function<Exception,@NonNull E> errorMapper)
      Wraps a throwing function in a Result, mapping exceptions with the provided function. If function succeeds: returns Ok(value) If function throws: returns Err(errorMapper(exception))
      Type Parameters:
      T - the input type
      R - the success type
      E - the error type
      Parameters:
      fn - the throwing function to execute
      input - the input value
      errorMapper - function to map exceptions to error type
      Returns:
      Ok if successful, Err with mapped exception if it throws

    • isOk

      boolean isOk()
      Returns true if this Result represents a successful operation.
      Returns:
      true for Ok, false for Err
      See Also:
      • isErr()

    • isErr

      boolean isErr()
      Returns true if this Result represents a failed operation.
      Returns:
      true for Err, false for Ok
      See Also:
      • isOk()

    • unwrap

      @NonNull T unwrap()
      Returns the success value, throwing an exception if this is an error.
      Returns:
      the wrapped value
      Throws:
      ResultException - if this is Err
      See Also:
      • for throwing with a custom error message
      • for providing a default value

    • unwrapErr

      @NonNull E unwrapErr()
      Returns the error value, throwing an exception if this is a success.

      This is the inverse of unwrap().

      Returns:
      the wrapped error
      Throws:
      ResultException - if this is Ok
      See Also:
      • for throwing with a custom error message

    • unwrapOr

      @NonNull T unwrapOr(@NonNull T defaultValue)
      Returns the success value if present, otherwise returns the provided default value.
      Parameters:
      defaultValue - the value to return if this is Err
      Returns:
      the wrapped value if Ok, otherwise the default value

    • unwrapOrElse

      @NonNull T unwrapOrElse(@NonNull Supplier<@NonNull T> supplier)
      Returns the success value if present, otherwise computes a fallback value.
      Parameters:
      supplier - the supplier to call if this is Err
      Returns:
      the wrapped value if Ok, otherwise the result of calling the supplier

    • expect

      @NonNull T expect(@NonNull String message)
      Returns the success value if present, otherwise throws an exception with the given message.

      Similar to unwrap(), but allows you to provide a custom error message for better debugging and error reporting. The error value is discarded.

      Parameters:
      message - the error message to use if this is Err
      Returns:
      the wrapped value
      Throws:
      ResultException - with the provided message if this is Err
      See Also:
      • for a version without custom message

    • expectErr

      @NonNull E expectErr(@NonNull String message)
      Returns the error value if present, otherwise throws an exception with the given message.

      This is the inverse of expect(String). Use this when you're certain the operation failed and need to extract the error with a custom message.

      Parameters:
      message - the error message to use if this is Ok
      Returns:
      the wrapped error
      Throws:
      ResultException - with the provided message if this is Ok
      See Also:
      • for a version without custom message

    • map

      <U> @NonNull Result<U,E> map(@NonNull Function<T,@NonNull U> fn)
      Transforms the success value by applying a function, if present.

      This is the primary way to transform values inside a Result without unwrapping and re-wrapping. If this is Err, the function is not called and the error is propagated unchanged.

      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the transformed value
      Parameters:
      fn - the function to apply to the success value
      Returns:
      Ok with the transformed value if this is Ok, otherwise Err unchanged
      See Also:
      • for transformations that return Results

    • mapErr

      <F> @NonNull Result<T,F> mapErr(@NonNull Function<E,@NonNull F> fn)
      Transforms the error value by applying a function, if present.
      Type Parameters:
      F - the type of the new error
      Parameters:
      fn - the function to apply to the error value
      Returns:
      Ok unchanged if this is Ok, otherwise Err with the transformed error
      See Also:
      • for transforming success values

    • flatMap

      <U> @NonNull Result<U,E> flatMap(@NonNull Function<T,@NonNull Result<U,E>> fn)
      Transforms the success value with a function that returns a Result.
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of value in the returned Result
      Parameters:
      fn - the function that returns a Result
      Returns:
      the result of applying the function if this is Ok, otherwise Err unchanged
      See Also:
      • for transformations that can't fail
      • for an alias with emphasis on sequencing

    • and

      <U> @NonNull Result<U,E> and(Result<U,E> other)
      Returns the provided Result if this is Ok, otherwise returns this Err.

      Implements logical AND behavior, both Results must succeed for the final result to succeed.

      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the other Result's success value
      Parameters:
      other - the Result to return if this is Ok
      Returns:
      other if this is Ok, otherwise this Err
      See Also:
      • for a lazy, function-based version

    • andThen

      <U> @NonNull Result<U,E> andThen(@NonNull Function<T,@NonNull Result<U,E>> fn)
      Applies a function that returns a Result if this is Ok, otherwise returns this Err.

      This is essentially an alias for flatMap(Function), but emphasizes the sequencing/chaining aspect rather than the flattening behavior. The name comes from Rust's Result API.

      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of value in the returned Result
      Parameters:
      fn - the function to apply if this is Ok
      Returns:
      the result of applying the function if this is Ok, otherwise this Err
      See Also:
      • for the same behavior with different emphasis

    • or

      @NonNull Result<T,E> or(@NonNull Result<T,E> other)
      Returns this Result if it's Ok, otherwise returns the provided alternative.

      Implements logical OR behavior - returns the first successful Result. Use this for fallback strategies where you want to try alternative approaches if one fails.

      Parameters:
      other - the alternative Result to use if this is Err
      Returns:
      this Result if Ok, otherwise other
      See Also:
      • for a lazy version

    • orElse

      @NonNull Result<T,E> orElse(@NonNull Supplier<@NonNull Result<T,E>> supplier)
      Returns this Result if it's Ok, otherwise computes an alternative.

      Lazy version of or(Result). The supplier is only called if this Result is Err. Use this when the fallback is expensive to compute or has side effects.

      Parameters:
      supplier - the supplier to call if this is Err
      Returns:
      this Result if Ok, otherwise the result of calling the supplier

    • ok

      @NonNull Option<T> ok()
      Converts this Result to an Option of the success value.

      Discards the error information and returns Some if successful, None if failed. Use this when you only care about whether the operation succeeded, not why it failed.

      Returns:
      Some containing the success value if Ok, otherwise None
      See Also:
      • for converting to an Option of the error

    • err

      @NonNull Option<E> err()
      Converts this Result to an Option of the error value.

      Discards the success information and returns Some if failed, None if successful. Use this when you want to collect or process errors while ignoring successes.

      Returns:
      Some containing the error value if Err, otherwise None
      See Also:
      • for converting to an Option of the success value

    • contains

      boolean contains(@NonNull T value)
      Returns true if this is Ok and contains the given value. For Ok: returns true if the wrapped value equals the given value For Err: returns false
      Parameters:
      value - the value to check for
      Returns:
      true if Ok and contains the value, false otherwise

    • containsErr

      boolean containsErr(@NonNull E error)
      Returns true if this is Err and contains the given error. For Ok: returns false For Err: returns true if the wrapped error equals the given error
      Parameters:
      error - the error to check for
      Returns:
      true if Err and contains the error, false otherwise

    • inspect

      @NonNull Result<T,E> inspect(@NonNull Consumer<T> consumer)
      Calls the provided consumer with the wrapped value if Ok. Returns this Result for chaining. For Ok: calls consumer with the wrapped value, returns this For Err: does nothing, returns this
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer to call if Ok
      Returns:
      this Result for method chaining

    • inspectErr

      @NonNull Result<T,E> inspectErr(@NonNull Consumer<E> consumer)
      Calls the provided consumer with the wrapped error if Err. Returns this Result for chaining. For Ok: does nothing, returns this For Err: calls consumer with the wrapped error, returns this
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer to call if Err
      Returns:
      this Result for method chaining

    • zip

      <U> @NonNull Result<Pair<T,U>,E> zip(@NonNull Result<U,E> other)
      Combines this Result with another, returning Ok only if both are Ok. For Ok(a) and Ok(b): returns Ok(Pair(a, b)) For any Err: returns the first Err encountered
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the other Result's Ok value
      Parameters:
      other - the Result to zip with
      Returns:
      Ok containing both values if both are Ok, otherwise the first Err

    • zipWith

      <U, R> @NonNull Result<R,E> zipWith(@NonNull Result<U,E> other, @NonNull BiFunction<T,@NonNull U,@NonNull R> fn)
      Combines this Result with another using a combining function. For Ok(a) and Ok(b): returns Ok(fn(a, b)) For any Err: returns the first Err encountered
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the other Result's Ok value
      R - the result type
      Parameters:
      other - the Result to zip with
      fn - the function to combine the values
      Returns:
      Ok with combined value if both are Ok, otherwise the first Err

    • transpose

      <U> @NonNull Option<Result<U,E>> transpose()
      Transposes a Result of an Option into an Option of a Result. For Ok(Some(value)): returns Some(Ok(value)) For Ok(None): returns None For Err(error): returns Some(Err(error))
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the inner Option's value
      Returns:
      the transposed Option

    • ifOk

      void ifOk(@NonNull Consumer<T> consumer)
      Calls the provided consumer if this is Ok. For Ok: calls consumer with the wrapped value For Err: does nothing
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer to call if Ok

    • ifErr

      void ifErr(@NonNull Consumer<E> consumer)
      Calls the provided consumer if this is Err. For Ok: does nothing For Err: calls consumer with the wrapped error
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer to call if Err

    • ifOkOrElse

      void ifOkOrElse(@NonNull Consumer<T> onOk, @NonNull Consumer<E> onErr)
      Calls onOk if this is Ok, or onErr if this is Err. For Ok: calls onOk with the wrapped value For Err: calls onErr with the wrapped error
      Parameters:
      onOk - the consumer to call if Ok
      onErr - the consumer to call if Err

    • stream

      @NonNull Stream<T> stream()
      Converts this Result to a Stream. For Ok: returns a Stream containing the single value For Err: returns an empty Stream
      Returns:
      a Stream with 0 or 1 elements
